awd_titl_txt: Fiduciary Duty, Financial Regulation, and the Market for Retirement Products
awd_abstract_narration:
The total amount of assets in retirement accounts exceeds $25 trillion, and there is rightly a large amount of policy discussion surrounding regulating the market for retirement products.  The primary goal of this research is to focus on fiduciary duties -- regulations designed to ensure that agents act in their clients' best interest -- imposed on various agents in the retirement system. This research aims at (1) providing empirical evidence on the effects of the efficacy of these regulations and (2) studying the effects of alternate regulatory proposals on the structure of the retirement market. The investigators first study the market of financial advice. The United States is in the middle of a protracted debate over the merits of imposing fiduciary duty on broker-dealers selling retirement products, which partially involves trading off the potential for aligning incentives of the clients with those of the adviser with the costs of an excessive regulatory burden. The investigators also study the market of employer-provided defined contribution plans, like 401(k) plans, when plan managers for certain plans are subject to fiduciary duties imposed through the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  This research studies how employer-trustee bargaining can influence the fees and plan offerings and examines regulations to restrict either fees or plan offerings, which can have important distributional consequences for a market in which investment options and costs are directly tied to one's place of employment. The investigators bring previously unexplored data to these questions and develop new methods for studying choices in the presence of multiple decision makers.

This research has three prongs.  First, the investigators leverage a transactions-level dataset from a major financial services provider to study the effects of fiduciary duty on product choice.  This research utilizes a differences-in-differences approach, comparing across states that impose differential fiduciary duties on broker-dealers and using investment advisers regulated at the federal level as a control. The investigators then supplement this reduced-form analysis with a model of selective entry into the market for financial advice.  Second, this project develops a structural model of discrete choice in which choices are determined not just by consumer utility but also by (possibly biased) advice.  Estimates from this model will help decompose the mechanisms through which fiduciary duty operates and also provide guidance on alternate reforms; it will also provide a framework for analyzing advice in other markets.  Finally, the investigators use data on the fee structure and plan offerings of the universe of ERISA-compliant defined contribution plans to develop a model of bargaining between employers and plan providers to quantify the level to which various parties internalize plan costs.  The model also allows for studying the effect of imposing most-favored-nation clauses on fees or plan offerings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded two major projects related to financial regulation in the market for retirement products.

Project 1: Fiduciary Duty and the Market for Financial Advice

In the first project, we study the impact of fiduciary duty---the requirement that financial advisers act in the best interest of their clients---on the number of advisers in a market and the type of advice they offer. The United States is in the middle of protracted debate about fiduciary duty, with federal agencies, state legislatures, and courts each weighing in on whether advisers should have this duty. Proponents argue that fiduciary duty alleviates conflicts of interest and improves outcomes for clients. Opponents argue that they only increase the cost of doing business, with little impact on actual advice.

The US already has variation induced by state court rulings ("common law") on whether broker-dealers have fiduciary duty. We collected data from a large financial services provider for every (deferred) annuity sold from 2013-15. Using this variation and data, we find that broker-dealers in states in which they have fiduciary duty sell products that have higher risk-adjusted returns---by 25 basis points on average. We investigate the source of these differences at length and show that they stem from differences in the types of annuities that are sold, along with their fees. We also document that there are fewer broker-dealer firms in such markets.

Next, we develop an economic model to understand these results. Our model suggests that there fiduciary duty operates through both a fixed cost channel, i.e., a direct impact of fiduciary duty on the cost of doing business, and an advice channel, i.e., a direct deterrence for offering "low-quality" advice. Using our model, we investigate the impacts of different stringencies of fiduciary duty to approximate the different proposals put forth by various agencies. We find that these different proposals all dominate directly regulating the set of firms allowed to operate in the market.

This project led to a working paper that is currently revise and resubmit at Econometrica, co-authored by Vivek Bhattacharya, Gaston Illanes, and Manisha Padi. We have presented our results are various academic and practitioner conferences. This paper has been cited by the SEC, the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in their ruling on Regulation Best Interest, and by the DOL in their 2023 Fiduciary Rule proposal.

Project 2: The Design of Defined Contribution Plans

Defined contribution plans comprise the largest stock of retirement savings in the United States, with almost $10 trillion in assets under management. However, the availability and quality of these plans is determined by decisions taken by one's employer. As such, there is a lot of heterogeneity among workers in the quality of these plans. For instance, small employers typically have defined contribution plans with significantly higher expenses and fewer broad, low-fee investment options than do plans from large employers. How can policy help alleviate these discrepancies and improve the quality of plans offered by employers?

Low-quality plans could arise from two broad frictions. The first class of frictions are ones that one might call "preferences" or "conflicts of interest" between the employer and the employee. Employers might not know how to evaluate plans, or they might not internalize the negative impact a high-fee plan has on workers, or they may not face many legal ramifications of offering a low-quality plan. These issues may be related to firm size. The second class of explanations comes from "market power": plan providers might have market power over small employers, and the revenue structure of this industry might make it such that their exert this market power by offering low-quality plans.

We have data on plan structure and fees for all plans in the US with at least 100 participants. We develop an economic model to use this data and determine the relative extent of "conflicts of interest" and "market power." We find that roughly 1/3 of the difference between small and large employers (in terms of fees) can be explained by market power, and about 2/3 by preferences.

This observation has important implications for policy. Since market power plays a smaller role quantitatively, policies that directly incentivize competition or alleviate market power will likely have limited impacts on the quality of plans. Examples of such policies are subsidies for plan provision or multi-employer plans to encourage collective bargaining, both of which have been proposed by recent regulation like the SECURE Act. Instead, policies must directly regulate the design of these plans. Doing so comes at the cost that some employers will choose to no longer offer defined contribution plans. Our model provides a quantification of the effects of various different regulations.

This project also led to a working paper that is currently revise and resubmit at Econometrica, co-authored by Vivek Bhattacharya and Gaston Illanes.
